Research.Name: Microrobot Control
Research.Title: Control of multiple microrobots with multiscale magnetic field superposition
Research.Authors: E Steager, D Wong, J Wang, S Arora, V Kumar
Research.Venue: IEEE MARSS 2017 (Best Paper Runner Up, Top 3)
Research.Description: Controlled independent manipulation of multiple objects at cellular length scales in an open challenge with potential applications in life sciences (e.g. directed drug delivery), microsurgery and advanced manufacturing. Magnetism has been studied as a means to perform such fine scale manipulation, but generating fields that discriminate between targets at small length scales is nontrivial. We present a system for simultaneous control of multiple magnetic microrobots with characteristic lengths on the order of 10 ŒºŒΩŒ±, which is based on the superposition of magnetic fields generated at centimeter scale (global) as well as micrometer scale (local).

Research.Name: DASA Photoswitch Molecule 2
Research.Title: A temperature-mapping molecular sensor for polyurethane-based elastomers
Research.Authors: B. P. Mason, M. Whittaker, J. Hemmer, S. Arora, A. Harper, S. Alnemrat, A. McEachen, S. Helmy, J. Read de Alaniz, and J. P. Hooper
Research.Description: This work focuses on the physics of the HTPB polymer, which is widely used in United States Naval explosives and rocket motor formulations. These composites are often subjected to extreme temperatures, shocks, and pressures in the field, which has led to disasterous unintended detonations. Methods to better understand the behavior of these composites are highly desirable - this work presents a method for analyzing temperature localization in these composites with submicron spatial resolution.
